title: I am being sued by Sallie Mae and just got a summons yesterday. I have 30 days to respond. I have no idea what the next step?
question: How do I write a response? Also, I've been facing financial hardship for the past 2 years and I am currently unemployed. Where can I find an affordable attorney and if I do, is there a way to also get a Free Attorney?
answers:
Please see these similar Qs and the As provided:

If you have no meritorious defenses, then fighting this complaint may only increase your liability, ding you the plaintiff's legal fees and interest at a higher rate than the 10% post-judgment interest, andd delay the inevitable. If bankruptcy is a sensible option given your other debts and the size of this claim, see a bankrupcty attorney ASAP before this lawsuit goes any further.

https://www.avvo.com/legal-answers/need-the-name-of-the-form-or-number-of-the-form-to-291060.html

https://www.avvo.com/legal-answers/how-do-i-handle-a-summons-for-a-breach-of-contract-259683.html

https://www.avvo.com/legal-answers/can-i-still-settle-a-credit-card-debt-out-of-court-249343.html

Disclaimer: Please note that this answer does not constitute legal advice, and should not be relied on, since each state has different laws, each situation is fact specific, and it is impossible to evaluate a legal problem without a comprehensive consultation and review of all the facts and documents at issue. This answer does not create an attorney-client relationship.

When you file has little to do with when the trial is. It is based on your unique circumstances. Either way, it is very difficult bordering on impossible to get a student loan discharged in bankruptcy. Undue hardship means an inability to ever repay despite attempts to due so (the test is more complex, but this is it in a nutshell).

You can try contacting your local legal aid office for a low cost attorney if you qualify, but you are not entitled to counsel for a civil matter.

As for writing a response, if you were served with a complaint, you can usually just copy the format and address everything that was stated in the complaint. You either admit, deny or do neither and state the reason why (usually if you do not have and cannot get the information to do either, you must state so and deny).

I would suggest that you consult with a bankruptcy attorney who can help you with timing and discuss whether you even need to respond given that you will be filing a bankruptcy petition. I doubt you will find an attorney who will do this for nothing because it is difficult to do.
